node.title: Applying for jobs in the academic sector
node.description: Guidance on how to apply for jobs in the academic sector.
node.keywords: academia, research, phd, post-doctoral, academic, academic sector, jobs, apply

rich_text_content.text: If you're looking for opportunities in academia after your PhD, you're likely to be applying for:
a postdoctoral research position (most common in scientific and technical subject areas)
a junior lectureship or fellowship (most common in arts and humanities subject areas).
The most common way to apply for academic jobs is to submit a university application form, along with an academic CV (curriculum vitae) and covering letter.
You could send out a speculative CV to the head of each research group in your field, to see if there are any current vacancies you can apply for.
Tips

list_item.text: You must submit a well-written and carefully researched application.
Find out as much as you can about the university and the department you're applying to, such as what is taught within the department and what you could contribute to the curriculum.

During your PhD study you may have focussed on a research topic in detail. For academic job applications try to focus primarily on the knowledge gained and output (in the form of publications) from your research. You also need to show experience of, or the potential to, generate research funding, in addition to teaching and supervision skills.

Look carefully at the person specification and make sure you fulfil the essential criteria. If you don’t have the desirable criteria, it’s still worth applying – make the most of the knowledge and skills you do have.

If an advert gives the name of someone to whom you can make informal enquiries, use this as an opportunity to find out more about the job and make a positive impression. Email the contact to ask when it would be convenient to phone. Have some questions prepared, for instance about the balance of teaching to research, or the administrative duties in the post. Don’t ask questions that have already been answered in the job description and person specification.
Work your way through the person specification and make sure you have given evidence in your application form, CV and covering letter that shows you have the relevant experience and knowledge.

rich_text_content.text: If you're successful in your job application and receive an interview offer, have a look at our advice on preparing for a job interview.

node.title: Learning from feedback
node.description: Take the time to consider the feedback on your assignments to ensure future improvement.
node.keywords: feedback, TMA feedback, assignment feedback, how to use feedback,PT3

rich_text_content.text: As well as marking the work, your tutor provides comments and advice on the content of your assignment, and on your skills in communicating your ideas.

quote_text.text: Marking assignments is how we assess progress and ensure that students process the module material and learn. It's easy to just look at the grade and put the assignment away but the feedback I give is individual to each student. It's important to address misunderstandings so they aren't repeated in other assignments or in the exam.

fields.audio_title: Mick's advice on dealing with feedback

audio_transcript.text: Mick: My name's Mick. I live in Milton Keynes in Buckinghamshire, and I'm currently studying Discovering Science S103 with the Open University. Traditionally my experience in higher education has been in the humanities.

I was quite well informed on my subject matters, but I was also quite opinionated, and I was also quite subjective in my thinking, and I was quite stubborn. I didn't take very well to criticism. I didn't like people questioning my views. So you can imagine, in my first few assignments on the course, that there was obviously a lot of feedback from my tutor in their comments. And, of course, the tutor's feedback would correspond to that and say, "Oh, you know, this is a general statement" or "This is too journalistic". And basically "you need to provide more evidence for your views and opinions, and back them up with other academic writers to produce a more objective conclusion".

But I still continued to make the mistakes. And I remember an assignment shortly after that. I thought I'd written a magnum opus, and I got the tutor's feedback, covered in tutor's comments all over the place, saying "this is all journalistic ... too emotive ... what a sweeping general statement that is". And, of course, it was no surprise that this essay was plastered in comments. All good feedback, I mean, it's all feedback, it's all comments that are designed to help you. But at the end of it my tutor wrote that "Mick, you obviously know your subject matter rather well. However, with all due respect, you do tend to go at it like a brim and firestone preacher thundering from the pulpit". And, of course, I can understand that now. But, at the time, I didn't see it that way. I thought well, "What's wrong with my essay? I thought it was brilliant. How dare you criticise me". And, of course, now I can look back and read the essay and agree with her. But, at the time, I didn't see it that way. At the time I thought "How dare she criticise me? This is my magnum opus and, I would not be challenged this way".

I remember the way I dealt with it at the time, 'cos it's not easy taking that kind of criticism, and what I did was leave it for a couple of days, and then sheepishly go back to my essay and re-read it, and then re-read all the comments, and then give it a couple of days to absorb the comments and think about them. And, after a while I would look back at the comments and say, "Hmm, OK. Yeah, I can see what you mean. Yeah, you've got a point there". And what I did subsequently was try and hone that in, that feedback, into my next few assignments, and be a little bit less subjective and a bit more objective, and avoid the sweeping statements and the journalistic lingo and things. And that was a big help. But I still had a few weaknesses. Some of my writing could still be a little bit too subjective. And sometimes I would neglect to contrast other arguments from other academic writers.

Yes, so studying at postgraduate level, I was doing a masters in humanities, back on to the old history thing. And, of course, at that level, you have to be thoroughly objective. There's no room for emotive language at all. You wouldn't succeed at all in any capacity at that level. And, again I had to go through a process of learning where I'd get lots of feedback from my OU tutor, particularly in my first year, and to a certain degree my second year, where you'd have to justify everything you'd written, and back it up with evidence, not just with evidence from other writers and contrasting them, 'cos that's what you do at first degree level ... at postgraduate level you have to use more evidence, more primary evidence to back up what you're saying. So that proved a bit of a challenge.

Yes, so ultimately the lessons that I've learnt throughout my access course and university and at postgraduate level is to take note of what your tutor's saying, and actually use the feedback that they give as an opportunity to learn. I know, if you're not used to academic writing, it can be quite a a shock sometimes, a bit of a struggle to absorb your tutor's comments initially, 'cos you think "Oh my God, what have I done wrong? Why all these comments? Oh I must be really stupid". It's nothing to do with that. Your tutor's not there to undermine your confidence. He or she are not there to make you look stupid. They're there to help you. And they're there to try and help you improve your academic skills. So really, ultimately what you need to be doing is taking note of your tutor, and have a talk with your tutor. That's what they're there for. You can have a talk to them too, discuss issues further and basically absorb what they're trying to say. And then, try and incorporate what you've learnt into your next assignment, and so on and so forth. And you go through a process of learning. By the end of it, you'll find that you've got the skills that you need at academic level to succeed.

rich_text_content.text: When you get your assignment back, you’ll no doubt look at the grade first and then look at your tutor’s comments. Try to be objective in how you react and use the suggestions below to build on your skills.
Read carefully your tutor’s comments on the assignment and the PT3 form.
Mark anything that you don’t understand and want to ask your tutor about.
Take note of issues to do with your structure and presentation.
Use a tutor-marked assignment (TMA) review form (RTF, 456 KB) to note any suggestions for future improvement.
Keep your feedback in one place and occasionally return to it to identify themes that keep coming up.
Speak to your tutor, or review material on this site for ideas on how to improve.

Take twenty minutes to review your assignment. If you want to check how you're doing on the module so far, you can use the assessment calculator (if available for your module). Find out more about estimating your module results and general assessment and exams matters.

note_body.text: For modules with no exam or EMA, your end-of-module tutor-marked assignment (emTMA) can't be collected until your final module result is issued. You'll be able to download the assignment and PT3 with comments from your tutor in the normal way when you've had your result.

rich_text_content.text: For an example of tutor feedback see K100 - Understanding Health and Social Care (PDF 59KB). You will get a sense of how OU tutors give feedback on such modules from the comments in this example. Tutors tailor any feedback according to the needs of each particular student, however, the comments here are designed to coach students in general assignment writing skills.

node.title: Choosing a web browser
node.description: Find out which web browsers the Open University supports and why it's important to upgrade to the latest versions.
node.keywords: Internet Explorer, Apple Safari, Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Windows 8 mode, 8.1, Microsoft Edge, what browser should I use, web support, web browser help, which browser, Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Edge Legacy, Safari, choosing a browser, help with browsers, latest version browser

primary.introduction_text: Open University websites have been designed and tested to fully support commonly used browsers running on desktop PCs, laptops, tablets, and mobile phones.

rich_text_content.text: A web browser is a software application which fetches information from the Web and displays it on your device's screen. It's worth checking you are using an up-to-date web browser to reduce any snags that come along when using the web and it makes sense to have more than one installed (for example, Google Chrome as well as Edge).
Recommended browsers for use with OU systems
We recommend the latest versions of the following browsers:

image_source.alt: Image showing the four main browsers logos and names, Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Mozilla Firefox and Apple Safari.

rich_text_content.text: All of these browsers have versions that are compatible with up to date operating systems such as Windows, macOS, iOS and Android, except for Apple Safari which is only available on macOS and iOS systems.
If you're not using the latest version of your browser you will still be able to access and use OU websites but they may not function properly.
Upgrading to the latest version

All browsers and upgrades are free to install but you must take care to download your chosen web browsers from their official sites.  It's important to upgrade to the latest version as they become available for the following reasons:
Newer browsers often have features that make websites more accessible.
Older browsers may not be able to display content properly.
Older browsers could compromise your online security.
Unsupported browsers

When companies choose to stop supporting old versions of their browsers, the issues which may occur can't be fixed so it's advisable to upgrade as soon as you can. The following browsers are no longer supported:

image_source.alt: Image showing two unsupported browsers, Internet Explorer and Microsoft Edge Legacy.

rich_text_content.text: If you're using either of these browsers you need to update now. If you need help with this try searching the web for 'how to update my browser'. What is my browser may be a good place to start.

node.title: Listening to your study material
node.description: Ways you can listen to your module materials
node.keywords: Daisy books, daisybook, daisy talking book, audio, audiobook, listen, text-to-speech, text to speech, screen reader, Thunder, WebbIE, Balabolka, NVDA screenreader, VoiceOver, blind, partially sighted, visual impairment, read aloud, dolphin easyreader

primary.introduction_text: There are several reasons why you might want to listen to your study materials. For example, it could be that you struggle to read materials in print or on screen due to a visual impairment, a specific learning difficulty such as Dyslexia or because you experience migraines.

rich_text_content.text: Audio versions of module materials can be useful when you're on the move, on your daily commute, when travelling, or when working or otherwise away from home. You can also listen while doing other activities, such as household chores. Whatever the reason, there are several options available for you to consider when working with your OU module materials.
DAISY talking books

DAISY talking books are audio representations of your module materials with built in navigation and accessibility features. This means you can listen to the study text at the same time as viewing it on screen. However, it should be noted that DAISY books are not a replacement for your primary module materials and some content, such as interactive content on your module website, might not be available in this format.

If DAISY talking books are available for a module, all students can download and use them. However, for copyright reasons, some content (such as set books) may only be available to students who’ve told us they have a disability.
Locating DAISY talking books for your module

If available for your module, you can locate DAISY talking books in the ‘Resources’ section of your module website. Visit your module website and click on the ‘Resources’ tab. Navigate to the ‘Downloads’ link and then scroll down the page to locate the heading ‘Module materials in DAISY digital talking book format’.

If you have a declared disability and use a bespoke DAISY Player (such as a Plextalk disc player or Victor Stream SD card player) we can arrange for DAISY talking books to be sent to you by post in CD-ROM or SD card format.
Playing DAISY talking books

The best way to play DAISY talking books is through a free software package or App called EasyReader. The EasyReader App allows DAISY talking books to be played on Android and iOS based devices. You can install the EasyReader software from the Dolphin website and by following the onscreen instructions. Once you have the app and have it open, you'll find useful user guides by pressing F1 on your keyboard.
For more information on DAISY books, how to download the relevant software and alternative options for listening, see the guidance in the OU Computing Guide.
Once you've got the software ready you can try a sample file of a talking book (ZIP, 5.4 MB).
Text-to-speech

Text-to-speech software reads aloud the text within web pages or documents on your computer or device. Depending on the software you use and how you use it, you can listen to whole pages and documents or choose specific parts of the text to be read back to you. If you find reading from a screen difficult, using text-to-speech software alongside reading the text can make it easier to read and understand.

You should be able to use most text-to-speech software directly with your module website and other digital files and software for your module. In addition, most modules also offer a range of materials in different formats  that you can try with text-to-speech software depending on your needs.  However, some formats may be missing certain elements of materials present on your module website such as the ability to show video or other interactive content which you will need to take into consideration.

Most operating systems and devices now have text-to-speech already built in. My Computer My Way by AbilityNet is a useful resource and may have more specific information about what is available to you. There is also a wide range of text-to-speech software available to download. Different software may be more appropriate for you than others depending on your individual needs and the device or operating system you are using. For example, you may want to consider the voice options available. If you would prefer a more natural sounding voice to a synthetic voice or a voice with a certain accent, this is something you can look for when choosing your preferred text-to-speech software.
A note about screen readers

It is worth noting that text-to-speech is different from using a screen reader or screen reading software. Screen readers are primarily used by people who are blind or partially sighted and are intended to more fully replace the visual experience of navigating and reading on screen. You can find out more about screen readers and other assistive technologies in the OU Computing Guide. If you think that a screen reader would better suit your needs, the article Blind or partially sighted tells you more about what adaptations may be helpful to you. You can also contact your student support team (SST) for advice and support.
Useful links

rich_text_content.text: Converting materials into accessible formats

If you have a disability, the Library has information on how you can convert materials into more accessible formats, including audio, through SensusAccess.  For more information on this and other support the Library provides visit the Library page on Disabled user support.
Further support

If you have told us about, or now want to tell us and provide evidence of, a disability or health condition, you may be eligible to request adjustments such as assistive technology or printed materials. You can also contact the Disability Support team to discuss your needs.

node.title: Psychology and Counselling skills and careers
node.description: Skills, career opportunities and employment related to study of psychology and counselling
node.keywords: psychology, counselling, psychology and counselling, skills, careers

rich_text_content.text: Opportunities for psychology graduates are so wide ranging that there is potential to find employment across all sectors, including health-related professions.
Skills you can develop

As well as the specific subject knowledge gained from studying for an OU degree, you'll develop many transferable and work-related skills that are highly valued by employers and which will increase your employability.
Your psychology studies will develop your ability to:
learn about the fundamental conceptual issues in psychology
understand the different ways in which psychological knowledge can be constructed
develop a range of research skills
interpret, use, evaluate and present evidence and data
appreciate how psychologists use evidence derived from research to contribute to debates on matters such as ageing, crime, education, employment, forensic science, mental health and relationships
combine your study of psychology with other disciplines, such as philosophy, law, computer science, biology, business, education and health science.

Studying the OU Foundation Degree in Counselling will enable you to develop skills that appeal to employers such as communication and literacy, problem solving and self-management. You’ll also gain professional skills from the Foundation degree that will be transferable to many other roles including the ability to:
practice safely and effectively in a recognised model of counselling
act in accordance with the relevant legal, ethical and procedural boundaries
make professional judgements and interventions
reflect on, review and audit your professional practice.
To see specific learning outcomes of qualifications in this area go to OU Psychology and Counselling Courses and follow the link to the learning outcomes under course details.

The OU Careers and Employability Services define employability as 'A set of capabilities and achievements that support students in developing their careers, raising their aspirations and enhancing their contribution to society'. You can view the full Student Employability Policy Statement on our website.

The Student Employability Profiles on the Advance HE website details many skills that employers value. You will also find information about employability skills developed through study of specific degree subjects at What can I do with my degree? on the Prospects website.

Whatever your motivations for study, your goals and career aspirations, you are entitled to supported personal development planning either as part of your study or through optional activities such as FutureYOU which you can find on your Study home site.

Having a psychology degree can open up varied exciting possibilities and lead to graduate opportunities in a range of fields or to further clinical training. Find out more of what you can do with a Psychology degree on the Prospects website. As a registered OU student, you can also find careers information tailored to your qualification on your Study home site under the Succeed tab.
Destination statistics

All UK graduates are invited to complete the Graduate Outcomes survey 12-15 months after graduation. Of the OU Psychology graduates and Foundation Degree in Counselling holders who responded in 2022, 62% were employed, a further 6% were running their own business, 17.7% were undertaking further study and 17% were engaged in other activities or caring responsibilities.
Graduates had found work most commonly in the NHS, mental health organisations, social work and social care fields, education sector and in the civil service and local councils, among others.
OU qualifications
Find out more about undergraduate study and postgraduate study in Psychology.
Find out about all undergraduate and postgraduate qualifications at OU Courses.

node.title: Struggling with assignments
node.description: How to cope with your assignments if you are struggling with the demands of your studies.
node.keywords: Essay, assignment, tma, etma, struggling, difficulty, difficult, hard, writing, extension, deadline, cut-off

related_links_description.text: For all policies relating to assessment and exams.

primary.introduction_text: Even if your study has been going well, it’s not unusual to find some assignments difficult. You may be struggling to get to grips with the assignment itself or perhaps other things are getting in the way of your study time. You may even feel that you can’t cope, and wonder whether to give up the module altogether.

rich_text_content.text: If you're getting behind in your study you may find it difficult to complete all your assignments. Talk to your tutor - and ask them to suggest ways to catch up, tell you where you should focus your efforts and if there's any material you can miss out.
Some tips if you're struggling
Think about how much work you’ve already done and the assignments you’ve completed. You may find one part of study difficult, but you’ll soon move on to something different.

Keep up at least a small amount of study, even if it’s just making some notes or working out what you need to do next. Remember too that you don't need to pass every assignment with high marks in order to pass the module.
Ask to extend the deadline

If a temporary problem such as a minor illness or work commitment is preventing you from finishing an assignment you can ask your tutor for a little more time. You must ask your tutor before the assignment cut-off date. Note that extensions are more restricted if it is the final TMA on the module. See getting an extension to your assignment deadline.
Submit as much as possible
It’s in your interest to submit as much assignment work as possible – the marks you’d get from a part-completed assignment are better than nothing at all.

Some assignments aren’t compulsory and you may be able to pass your module without submitting or passing every assignment. Check your assessment strategy (via the Assessment section on StudentHome) to find out whether your module has any compulsory assignments.
Don’t panic

If you do fail or miss an assignment and it’s not compulsory, it doesn't necessarily mean you'll fail your module overall. Check your assessment strategy text on the Assessment section of StudentHome to see which assignments are compulsory and what scores you need to get in order to pass the module. Take a look at Failing or missing an assignment for information on how your overall scores may be affected.
Improve your study skills

The way you study can make a big difference to your learning. You may find it useful to explore our online resources on how to tackle assignments. You may be able to get some additional support to help you overcome your immediate difficulty. Talk to your student support team to find out more.

primary.introduction_text: This page provides an indication of when each module’s exam is likely to be. You'll find the exact date and time of your exam under the Assessment tab of your module website.

heading.text: Where can I find more information?

rich_text_content.text: The University holds its exams at regular periods based on the module length and start date. Check StudentHome for your module start date and length and check the tables on this page to find out which period applies to you. Your module website study planner should also indicate the week in which your exam is scheduled. Exams are scheduled in the period immediately after formal teaching has ended. There is no choice about when your exam will take place.
Details of your exam will appear on your module website and on your StudentHome homepage as soon as they become available, usually about two weeks after your module start date.
If you’re a prospective student who’d like to query exam periods before you register for a module or qualification, please speak to an adviser in Student Recruitment.
If you’ve already registered for a module or qualification please contact your Student Support Team (SST) for advice.

rich_text_content.text: All students who receive a fail result and are eligible to resit their exam must sit at the next available exam opportunity for that module. You can’t sit a postponed exam or complete a resit more than 13 months after the original exam opportunity, or if three exam opportunities have passed.

Where an application for a discretionary postponement has been approved, you must sit the exam at the next available opportunity and within 13 months of the original exam opportunity. If you wish to request a discretionary postponement you may do so via the Discretionary postponement form.

Most resit exams for undergraduate modules take place approximately 12–16 weeks after the main exam opportunity and approximately six weeks after notification of results. Notification of the date of your resit is approximately four to five weeks before the exam.

Some modules may allow you to postpone your resit to the next exam opportunity, which could be as much as nine months later. If your module allows this, further information will be available from your module results notification page in StudentHome.

The Open University offers a range of support to students whose religion or beliefs may have an impact on their studies. Wherever possible we try to avoid setting exams that clash with major religious festivals.

However, if you are unable to complete your exam at the scheduled time for religious reasons, we may be able to make alternative arrangements for you, such as completing your exam on a different day. You’ll need to provide supporting evidence, for example from your religious leader, to show why your belief prevents you from completing the exam.
If you would like to request special arrangements for your exam, contact your SST no later than the date shown in the relevant table on Deadlines for changing exam arrangements.

Alternatively, if you are unable to complete your exam at the scheduled time or the alternative offered to you, you may be eligible to postpone your exam to the next opportunity. Supporting evidence, for example from your religious leader, will be required before permission can be granted. This evidence will need to demonstrate why your belief prevents you from completing the exam at the time offered. If you wish to request a discretionary postponement you may do so via the Exam, EMA or emTMA discretionary postponement form.

primary.introduction_text: All exams will now be delivered as a remote exam, which you take at home rather than face-to-face at an exam centre.

rich_text_content.text: Remote exams are intended to be taken at home, or in another location of your choice, using your own equipment and computer software. They're designed to be completed in three hours but the amount of time you will have to complete your exam varies from module to module. You can find all the details for your exam under the Assessment tab of your module website.

If you have an additional requirement based on disability or illness, you may be able to receive extra time or rest breaks to complete your remote exam as a reasonable adjustment. In exceptional cases you may be able to request other reasonable adjustments.
To request adjustments for exams, you’ll need to submit a request for reasonable adjustments form along with supporting evidence as soon as you can, and before the following deadlines:
Exams in March 2023 - request form/evidence to be received by 17 February 2023
Exams in April 2023 - request form/evidence to be received by 17 March 2023
Exams in June 2023 - request form/evidence to be received by 28 April 2023
Exams in September 2023 - request form/evidence to be received by 4 August 2023
Exams in October 2023 - request form/evidence to be received by 1 September 2023
Exams in December 2023 - request form/evidence to be received by 10 November 2023

note_body.text: If you need adjustments for your exam, you must submit this form and accompanying evidence, even if you've had adjustments approved for previous exams. Any agreed adjustments will be automatically carried forward for a resit or if you decide to postpone your exam. However, if you have more than one remote exam, you'll need to discuss the arrangements you need for each one with your Student Support Team (SST), as they won’t be automatically applied to every exam.

rich_text_content.text: If you have any concerns about this or any other aspect of your exam you should speak to your SST for further advice.

node.title: What is a student support team?
node.description: Your student support team is there to help you plan, arrange and succeed in your studies.

node.notes: Contact re attached requesting a call back page is Susie Murrihy

primary.introduction_text: Your student support team (SST) are specialists made up of experienced academics, educational advisers and other staff with subject-specific expertise.

rich_text_content.text: Your SST are your first point of contact if you have queries about:
difficulties with study, for example, extra help revising for exams
making changes to the modules or qualifications you’re studying or planning to study
options available if caring responsibilities are affecting your study
your tutorials, for example, timetables or extra arrangements
what to study next.
Your SST will also send you emails or sometimes call you with hints and tips for study; to remind you to take action on study administration or to provide support.
You can contact your SST by phone, webchat or email. Contact details for your SST are on Contact the OU.
Study Home is also a valuable resource for information and guidance about your qualification subject and future plans.
For any queries you have about the content of your module you should contact your tutor.
Why you may have more than one student support team

Your SST is automatically allocated depending on which qualification and/or modules you are studying. You may have more than one SST if the subject of your current module is significantly different to the subject of your qualification. You may also have more than one SST if you are studying multiple modules in different subject areas which are not linked to a qualification.

node.title: Preparing assignments
node.description: A methodical approach to assignments, from understanding the question to editing and getting your assignment in.
node.keywords: Preparing assignments, assignment planning, first assignment, drafting essays, drafting assignments, first TMA, help with assignment, help with TMA, proofreading, feedback, TMA feedback, assignment feedback, how to use feedback, presentation, assignment presentation, margins, fonts, font, formatting, format, line spacing, essay word limit, assignment word limit, word limit

rich_text_content.text: Don't be daunted by the prospect of your assignment. There is no single correct way of planning how to write your assignment. However, there are some common principles and if you work your way through the stages described below, you'll be on the right track.

quote_text.text: This year I was so busy at work, I just had time to do enough to pass the module.

rich_text_content.text: Try to plan ahead and allow plenty of time to read the assignment booklet and make sure that you understand the question. It might take longer than you expect to finish your first assignment but, like all study skills, it’ll get easier with practice.

Start by thinking about how much effort you can put into writing your assignment. Not all students can 'ace' every assignment, sometimes just doing enough is fine. So, first, decide what you want to achieve and what is realistic for you to achieve.
Organise a rough schedule for your work over the whole module and block out some time for completing assignments.
Identify potential contingency plans; find the assignments you could drop or do quickly if you had to.
Discuss with your tutor what you're hoping to achieve and what you want out of the module.
Read the module assessment guide on  your module website to find out:
What elements are involved in assessments. For example, assignments, interactive computer-marked-assignments (iCMA), an exam or end-of-module assessment (EMA), or a speaking assignment.
What flexibility exists. For example, some modules apply substitution or offer a choice of questions.

You should read the assessment strategy text for your module carefully (available from the module section of StudentHome) as it tells you what you need to do to pass your module. On most modules, you can estimate your module results by using the assessment calculator at any stage prior to the release of module results. If you have any queries, contact your Student Support Team or email Assessment Processing.
Presenting your assignment

Use your module assessment guide for instructions about how to present your assignment. If you can't find instructions or are unclear on the requirements for your particular module or assignment, you should contact your tutor for support.

If there are no specific instructions about formatting or presentation, you should submit your work in a clear font – such as Arial – in 12 point, using 1.5 or double line spacing and reasonably wide margins (for example, 2.5 cm).
Talk to others

If you have a tutor or study adviser, discuss any concerns about the assignment with them. Many modules have online forums relating to assignments and discussion around relevant subjects is common. So have a look at these before you tackle an assignment but do be wary of discussing your intended approach in too much detail.
Further information on preparing assignments
There are a range of study skills booklets available to students. You'll need to sign in to see them. The Preparing assignments booklet gives you further information on this subject.

node.title: Submitting your file in the correct format
node.description: How to change the format of your file to be compatible with the TMA system.
node.keywords: Cloud, OpenOffice, LibreOffice, Google docs, Apple iCloud, iCloud, submit by cloud, formatting, format, font, fonts, margin, margins, line spacing, essay word limit, assignment word limit, word limit

rich_text_content.text: Unless your study materials say otherwise, your tutor-marked assignment (TMA) must be saved in a file format compatible with Microsoft Word - that is with one of the following file extensions:
.doc - Microsoft Word document 1997-2003
.docx - Microsoft Word document 2007+
.rtf - Rich Text Format. A text file format used by Microsoft which can be read by most word processing software.
Some modules might allow, or even require, you to submit in one of the following formats (check the 'Assessment' tab on your module website to find out what is permitted on your module):
.pdf - Portable Document Format (where you would ordinarily submit your TMA on paper through the post, .pdf submissions may be permitted. See submitting a TMA on paper (PT3) for more information.)
.ppt - a PowerPoint presentation
.xls - an Excel document
.mp3 - MP3 audio files. Often used for spoken assessments on languages modules

.zip - zipped files. Several separate files compressed as a single file. This would apply to all modules where an assignment consists of more than one document. More information on how to zip files can be found in combining and compressing your files.
Other file formats are not accepted by the Online TMA/EMA service.

If you try to submit in another file format your submission will be rejected and you'll have to save your file in an accepted format and go through the submission process again. In most cases, you can use the File > Save As command and select an appropriate option, such as .docx or .pdf, from the ‘File format’ or 'Save as type' menu.
Presenting your assignment

Use your module assessment guide for instructions about how to present your assignment. If you can't find instructions or are unclear on the requirements for your particular module or assignment, you should contact your tutor for support.

If there are no specific instructions about formatting or presentation, you should submit your work in a clear font – such as Arial – in 12 point, using 1.5 or double line spacing and reasonably wide margins (for example, 2.5 cm).
Using Cloud applications

If you've created your TMA on a cloud application such as Office Online, Google Docs or Apple iCloud, you'll need to download or export your file into one of the accepted file formats and save it on your computer to submit it using the online TMA system. If you're unsure on how to do this, you'll need to refer to the Help section of the application you're using.

node.title: Styles, outlines, tables of contents and templates
node.description: Guidance on using styles effectively in documents.
node.keywords: Styles, outlines, table of contents, templates, documents, Word, fonts, font, font size, paragraph, heading, paragraph style, line spacing, margin, margins, format, formatting, essay word limit, assignment word limit, word limit, word count

primary.introduction_text: Using styles in documents saves you time and adds a useful underlying structure to the document. Once you've set up a template with styles that you like, you can keep a consistent appearance for all your documents. This article deals with the principles you should follow rather than the details of how to create a style template.

rich_text_content.text: The assessment resources on your module website will have details of the word count and line spacing rules and requirements for each of your assignments. If you can't find this or are unclear on the requirements for your particular module or assignment, you should contact your tutor for support.

If there are no specific instructions about formatting or presentation, you should submit your work in a clear font – such as Arial – in 12 point, using 1.5 or double line spacing and reasonably wide margins (for example, 2.5 cm).
Using styles

The styles in a document come from the template you use to create the document – the default Normal or Blank template. It might well be worth the effort to make your own template for your assignments so you have the styles you need readily to hand.

Styles provide a quick way to adjust the appearance of the text in your document. They invisibly label each chunk of text to show its status in a hierarchy of styles (for example, Heading 1, Heading 2, normal text).
There are two types of style: paragraph styles and character styles.
Paragraph styles affect the whole paragraph they’re applied to and can control the font, type size, type colour, space before and after the paragraph and interline spacing.
Character styles only affect the characters they’re applied to so the variables are just those that affect the appearance of characters such as font, colour etc.

node.title: When you're ready to study again
node.description: Some advice and study tips for when you're ready to return to study.
node.keywords: return to study, restricted, alert, academic progress, status, fail 3 modules, defer, withdraw

rich_text_content.text: The information here is relevant if you've withdrawn or deferred part way through, or have failed recent modules. The implications of what this means and how to apply for any restriction to be lifted can be found in the first page of this article, implications of unsuccessful study.
Take care with your future study choices if you've recently withdrawn from one or more modules or received a fail result.
Is this the right time to be embarking on another module?
It's important to make sure you've overcome any factors which may have disrupted your study in the past.

Take some time to reflect on your progress and your study goals. You may feel ready to return to study, but you need to think carefully about any potential issues that may affect your future academic progress and how you might manage them.
The OU Students Association (OUSA) provides several services to make sure you get the help you need. You'll find lots of advice and links to peer groups at OUSA help and support.

If you have a disability look at Timescales for getting disability support to arrange the support you need to reduce any barriers to study you may be facing. We have produced a set of booklets that may help.

If you have caring responsibilities (for a relative or breastfeeding a new baby for example) or if you’re pregnant, you may find you need extra support with your studies and exams. Our articles in life events and study outlines the support or arrangements you may be able to ask for, for your circumstances.
Make sure you:
Read the advice under the heading 'Am I ready' in the module description.
Look at examples of study materials provided including 'Taster' materials or 'Are you Ready For' guides.
Take account of the time you'll be expected to commit to study.
Reconsider your long term goals - the Qualification Planner on the Qualification page of StudentHome will help you to plan your route to a qualification.
Improving your study skills

You may decide you need to improve your study skills – look back at your assignment feedback to see if there are suggestions about study areas that need extra development. You can also use Your Learning Plan to help you plan how to develop your study skills.
In Study skills we have resources to help you succeed with topics like:
Using maths and statistics
Using a computer for your studies
English for Learning
Tackling assignments and managing the stress they can bring
Revising, exams, and assessment and techniques to boost your success
Tips on thinking, reading and taking notes.
Managing your time
Managing your time is a key element of successful study. We can offer lots of guidance on time management skills including:
planning and prioritising
finding a place to study
study goals
distractions and procrastination
helpful tips for time management.
Help with choosing your next module

Although many of our Level 1 modules include materials to help you develop skills needed for university study, you need reasonable levels of English language, numeracy and computing skills before taking on OU study.
You also need to be realistic about the demands OU study makes. Much of this information is provided in our online prospectus.
If you're studying with a specific career goal in mind, get in touch with our Careers and Employability Services.

node.title: Gathering your materials
node.description: Advice on where to start before writing your assignment and what you need to complete a successful piece of writing.
node.keywords: Preparing assignments, assignment planning, first assignment, drafting essays, drafting assignments, first TMA, help with assignment, help with TMA

rich_text_content.text: When you’re confident you understand what you’re being asked to do, take some time to think about how you'll go about writing your assignment. Then gather and check through all of the items you’ll need.
Remember to:
Keep your assignment question handy, so you can check you're staying on track.
Check to see what marks are allocated to each part of the assignment.
Consider how long you'll need (include time for planning, drafting, editing and proofreading before you send it in).
Go back through the notes you made and identify relevant module material for the assignment.
Keep a record of sources as you go for your reference section (see the OU Library's Bibliographic management page to learn more about reference management tools).
Selecting the evidence

Think about the types of evidence you'll need to support any arguments you make, such as quotes, tables and paraphrasing of other people's work. Ask yourself how each of these will help you to answer the assignment question and make sure to note where they come from for your reference list. If you need help to identify relevant material, check the learning outcomes for the assignment.
Reviewing your work

Review what you've done so far to make sure the key message that you're trying to put across reflects the requirements of the assignment. Check that you haven't missed any useful material from other parts of the module.

node.title: Get to know the OU
node.description: Make a start here by checking some information about studying with the OU.

article_purpose.text: This article is linked to from the advert space on StudentHome and is visible to brand new students only, those who have not yet chosen a module.

rich_text_content.text: If this is your first time studying with The Open University you may want to know what it's going to be like.
You'll study with other students, online from your home, work or anywhere convenient to you.
A dedicated tutor, an expert in your subject, supports you on each module.
Your tutor marks your assignments, answers your questions and meets with your tutor group either online or in person throughout your study.
Study materials are available online and available to download from your personal module website.
For some modules you'll be sent books and study materials if your module subject requires it.
You'll have a lot of flexibility but still have deadlines for assignments and exams.
How much time is needed
The amount of time you’ll spend studying each week will vary. You might, for example, need extra time just before an assignment or an exam.
Part-time study

If you want to study part-time, you'll need around 16–18 hours study time per week. Part-time study means completing 60 credits worth of study per year, for example, one 60 credit module, or two 30 credit modules. If you study 60 credits a year, an honours degree would usually take 6 years to complete.
Full-time study
We recommend that you don't study full-time in your first year.
Full-time requires around 32–36 hours study time per week.
It means completing 120 credits worth of study per year, for example, two 60 credit modules.
If you study 120 credits a year, an honours degree would usually take 3–4 years to complete.
If you have a full-time job, we recommend you study no more than 60 credits per year.
You may find our time planner useful to check how many hours per week you have available for study.
Get additional support if you have a disability

If you have a disability, including long-term health conditions, specific learning difficulties (such as dyslexia), or mental health difficulties you can get reasonable adjustments to support your study.

The support available includes financial help, specialist equipment and accessible study materials. We will also make reasonable adjustments to enable you to participate in tutorials and to take any exams you may have.
You can find out more about the range of support available, and how to apply once you're fully enrolled on a module, in our student Help Centre.
When can you enrol
Enrolment on modules for the new academic year opens in March and closes three weeks before the start of the module. For example, for modules starting in:
October, you can enrol from March to September
February, you can enrol from March to January.
If you have questions or are having difficulties enrolling, see help with payment and enrolment.
If you're ready to enrol and registration is open click the button below.
Contact us
If you have questions about studying, need help choosing modules or want to enrol over the phone, call Student Recruitment on +44 (0)300 303 5303 (Mon to Fri 08:00-17:30).

node.description: Learn the differences between essays, reports, oral languages assignments and short-answer questions.
node.keywords: Preparing assignments, assignment planning, drafting essays, drafting assignments, help with assignment, help with TMA, proofreading, essay structure, report writing, report structure, planning reports, drafting reports, oral assignments, language assignments, oral language assignments, presentations, presentation planning, short answer questions, precis, Précis, summary, short summary

rich_text_content.text: As you study you might be asked to submit assignments in different formats, such as essays, reports, short-answer questions, speaking assignments or a précis.
You can find out what types of assignments are expected for your module under the assessment tab on your module website. Ask your tutor if you need any clarification.

The advantage of tackling different types of assignment is that you'll have an opportunity to develop a wide range of skills. Assignments also provide evidence of your ability to communicate effectively in several ways.

Tackling new tasks such as writing a précis or report for the first time can be daunting, especially if you are new to academic study. But remember that support is available so don't hesitate to flag up any concerns with your tutor as early as possible.
There are a range of study skills booklets available to students. If you're not already signed in, sign in to see them all including Preparing assignments.
